content.description: Sit start low below the slab at a good right hand sidepull and a small sharp crimp for the left hand. Bump to the jug on the arete. Match, bring your feet around the arete and transition on to slopers on the arete. Mantle onto the slab above.
content.location: Sit start at the low point at the right end of the overhanging face.

content.description: Fun squeezing up the unique groove feature. Sit start the double arete and slap/squeeze your way up with some bad feet.
content.location: The obvious water groove on the "middle slice" of the boulder.

content.description: Hard undercling move to a jug. Move up to the lip and mantle.
content.location: Pretty much right on the trail just behind the fire ring. Start low on the undercling.

content.description: Sit start in the cave. Climb out the cave and up the double aretes until you can transition to easier terrain on the left arete to the top.Â
content.location: Climbs the downhill edge of the overhanging slice of Fort Rock. Start in the low cave.

content.description: Climb the double aretes to the top.
content.location: This climbs the narrow end of the "first slice" of the boulder.

content.description: Sit start on good edges then up and left to the arete. Grab the cool undercling and make a long move to a sloping shelf then jugs at the top.
content.location: Climbs the left end of the overhanging face just right of the arete and finishes at the highest point of the boulder.

content.description: Sit start on good edges. Move up and right through smallish holds to the lip.
content.location: Sit start in the right/middle of the overhanging face.

content.description: This is the main boulder here. It is split into three pieces like someone sliced a giant melon. The back slice being the best piece of rock. It is 12 feet tall and leans over quite a bit giving climbers a well featured overhanging face to climb on. Not to be missed are Cannon Fodder and Major General.
